--Well, there are--

--The liability under (ii) is a liability under this subparagraph, and the exception to little (ii) is only an exception to little (ii).

--which is a liability under this subparagraph.

--Absolutely, Your Honor.

But that convention, it seems to me, is much less strong than the fact that you don't read a word to mean one thing for purposes of one part of the... of the whole paragraph and another thing for the purposes of the rest.
Well, I mean, I think that that's the next thing--
And that is simply a flat contradiction.
--Well--
And... and the... the reading given by the court below produced no flat contradiction in the terms of the statute.
--Well, it... it flatly contradicted the standing meaning of the word subparagraph.
No... no contradiction within... within the statute itself.
Well--

--Well, Your Honor, I think that the principle or the canon that the specific controls the general is one that... that Your Honor set forth in the... in the Casey case, and many other cases have asserted it.
It isn't straightforward.
Only if--

--you're urging that one interpretation is better than another, and if there were an unavoidable conflict, I would agree that (iii) would... would overrule (ii), but it is not necessary to read (ii) that way.
--What you have to do, Your Honor, to take the approach that the court below took is ignore the established meaning of the word subparagraph.

--it seems to me that I should interpret it the way it is written.

That is correct.

Your Honor, I mean, there's a lot of speculation in a number of the briefs.

Justice O'Connor, I'm not certain what it meant.
Do you agree that the courts had interpreted it to apply to both little (i) and (ii)?
--I agree that that's what the opinions in the Dryden and the Mars case said, but I would point out that in both of those cases that was not the issue before the Court.
Well, isn't the difficulty with that... that the point that I raised with Mr. Ayer?
--Well, the answer is this subparagraph.
Well, no.
Well, the... the answer I believe is in... is in the context of the statute.
Well, the... you can look at that either way, it seems to me.
I would disagree with you because of the language, the word or.

--You have to understand that... that all three of these are very, very different.

--History suggests that most of those cases that came up... and if you look at them... in the early years were the technical cases.

That that applied only to clause (ii)?
